Award.AwardTitle: Multi-Dimensional Magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) Simulations of Chromospheric Dynamics Using a Complete Electrical Conductivity Tensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
Magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) processes play a key role in solar chromospheric physics. With prior NSF funding, the PI has developed a 1.5D MHD simulation of chromospheric dynamics, based on a model that included a complete space- and time-dependent electrical conductivity tensor, gravity, and an energy equation for magnetized multi-species plasmas of variable ionization (Kazeminezhad & Goodman, 2006). These efforts have been motivated by the concept that understanding chromospheric dynamics was critical to understanding solar atmospheric dynamics.

The PI now plans to parallelize the code and extend the existing model to the lower boundary of the solar photosphere. He will generalize the code to 2.5D, as well as simulate the heating rates and flow acceleration due to MHD and shock waves from the photosphere to the lower corona. He also will simulate the dynamics of horizontally localized, sub-resolution kiloGauss magnetic structures in the photospheric inter-network, estimating their contribution to heating the overlying chromosphere, and modeled the effect of photospheric magnetic flux emergence and magnetic footpoint shearing on chromospheric dynamics. The PI's team plans to estimate the importance of the proton viscosity tensor and the effect of proton magnetization in chromospheric heating by developing a 1.5D steady-state, finite thickness shock wave model, as well as a 2.5D linear wave model. Both models will include viscosity and electrical conductivity tensors, building upon previous work by the PI.

The PI's team will also contribute their time and research results to the West Virginia High Technology Consortium Foundation's education programs for grades 7-9 and 9-16. These ongoing programs are separately funded by the NSF under the Comprehensive Information Technology Education in Rural Appalachia (CITERA) and Expanding Pathways for Educational Development and Information Technology Experiences (ExPEDITE) programs.

Background: The Need for Space Weather Prediction for National and Economic Defense

 Space and Ground Based Assets: The United States and its allies have thousands of commercial and military satellites in orbit around Earth. Their number will continue to increase. They represent a large financial investment, and are an important part of the economy and national defense. They are a critical component of civilian and military communications networks, and provide surveillance and detection capability that protects soldiers in the field, informs policy decisions, and is an important part of tactical and strategic planning. The ground based part of the communications network, and the national electrical grid including the internet are major parts of the national infrastructure on which many critical services depend.

Vulnerability of Assets to Space Weather: As we rely more heavily on these increasingly extensive and complex electronic systems we become more vulnerable to their failure. These systems can be disrupted, damaged, and permanently disabled when they are exposed to high energy particles, radiation, and magnetic fields that propagate from the Sun to the Earth, and that are generated by explosions in the Sun's atmosphere called coronal mass ejections (CME's) and flares. Astronauts in space can also be harmed by the high energy particles and radiation.

The Need for Reliable Forecasting: Flares need to be predicted at least 24 hours in advance of their occurrence to provide enough time for defensive measures against their high energy particles and radiation to be implemented. CME's are the primary space weather threat. The danger from CME's is that the magnetic field they carry can cause large geomagnetic storms at Earth. These storms have damaged large sections of the electrical grid, causing blackouts, and have seriously disrupted satellite operations, in some cases causing the complete loss of communication satellite functionality. For CME's what is needed is an accurate prediction of the direction of the CME's magnetic field when it reaches Earth. The direction of this field determines the severity of the geomagnetic storm caused by the CME. Severe storms occur when the direction of this field is close to being anti-parallel to the Earth's magnetic field. In 1989 a geomagnetic storm caused a power blackout in Canada affecting 6 million people. The largest geomagnetic storm recorded occurred in 1859. It did not do serious damage because there were no spacecraft, or extensive electrical and communication systems at that time (telegraph systems were disrupted and destroyed). If a storm of this magnitude occurred today it would cause electrical and communication outages on a national scale, cause more than a trillion dollars in damage, probably cause loss of life, and it would take years to recover. Model based estimates show that a North American power grid blackout would impact GDP by about $30 billion per day. The cost of a 5 day blackout would exceed the $120 billion cost of Hurricane Katrina. The cost of a 2 week blackout would exceed the $500 billion cost of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. It could take 4 to 6 years to fully restore the power grid after a severe space weather storm, costing trillions of dollars. Less severe storms occur more frequently, and can be costly. For example, the Galaxy 4 communication satellite was completely and permanently disabled in 1998 by a CME, severely disrupting telecommunications in the US for several days.
